so here's a question for you there are
no volcanoes on the Olympic Peninsula
but there is a ton of basalt which is a
type of volcanic rock so how did it get
there well it wasn't the Cascades off to
the east instead scientists believe it
got there because 50 million years ago a
volcanic island called Silesia collided
with North America the story goes like
this more than 50 million years ago in
the Northeast Pacific Ocean an island
made primarily of volcanic rock appeared
today geologists call it Silesia Silesia
was attached to an oceanic tectonic
plate and over time that plate moved as
they tend to do specifically this one
went east and was slowly traveling
underneath the North American tectonic
plate or subducting if you watched her
Mount Olympus episode as the tectonic
plate moved Celestia moved along with it
and eventually about 50 million years
ago Silesia ran up against North America
in other scenarios that might have
actually been the end of the story
Celestia might have just disappeared
under the North American plate melted
and never been heard from again which
happens but recent studies suggest that
Silesia was too hot and buoyant for it
to subduct so instead it accreted on to
North America meaning that it got stuck
to the side of the tectonic plate and
eventually spread throughout the
landscape that's why the Olympic
Peninsula and the Pacific Northwest have
so much basalt not because of a bunch of
volcanoes but because of an ancient
traveling volcanic island geologists
found most of this out by studying the
rocks in this area as well as using
models like one published in 2014 that
used a bunch of data from rocks in
Washington and Oregon and you can find
evidence of this all over the place the
Silesia basalt stretches from Oregon to
British Columbia and it varies from 10
to 32 kilometers thick if you know what
to look for and have a good map you can
see it for yourself
on certain hiking trails or rock
outcroppings around here
